newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Microsoft sues Singapore mouse pirates.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft sues Singapore mouse pirates.

text.p: Microsoft Corp said on Monday it was taking legal action against five traders who were allegedly distributing fake computer mouse products.
The suits against computer component traders suspected of distributing counterfeit mouse products through the local market follows recent moves by Microsoft to curb piracy in Singapore.
Microsoft said in a statement these civil suits were the first in Southeast Asia against companies suspected of importing and distributing counterfeit computer mouse products.
It first introduced the mouse in Singapore in 1990 and sales of the product had been growing steadily until the emergence of large numbers of bogus versions last year.
The fake products appear to be manufactured from several different sources and sell at about half the cost of the original Microsoft Mouse.

"We have serious consumer protection issues that are at play here," Microsoft corporate attorney for Southeast Asia Christopher Austin said, adding that Microsoft's reputation for quality was at stake and the company had to act quickly.
Separately, the Alliance Against CD-ROM Theft (AACT), said the Singapore District Court meted the harshest sentence yet against piracy this month.
It said a man was convicted of possessing 454 copies of counterfeit computer programmes and sentenced to 27 months in jail and fined Singapore $181,600.
